awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  PPER:  Validation and Utilization of a New Tool for Citizen-Led Water Quality Monitoring in Agricultural Watersheds
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project tests a new tool that uses a smartphone app to test water quality. The app relies on the smartphone camera's ability to detect the color change on a chemical test strip to a much higher level of precision and more accurately than the human eye. The phone relays the data and test location to a database for access by the project researchers as well as citizen scientists.  The project goals are to determine the feasibility of using this app to accurately monitor water quality throughout a watershed, to assess user interest and engagement in using the app, and to help stakeholders identify water-quality "hot spots" for the potential implementation of projects to improve water quality. 

In this research project, a water quality monitoring smartphone app is being piloted with stakeholders in two separate field campaigns: Clear Creek Watershed (Fall 2017) in eastern Iowa (to collect preliminary data related to the app's accuracy, ease-of-use, and user experience) and Clear Creek and the Middle Cedar River watersheds (Spring and Summer 2018) in Iowa (to introduce the app to watershed management authorities and other water-quality monitoring volunteers). The two campaigns are providing sufficient data to determine the new app's potential for citizen-led monitoring to provide scientifically credible characterization of water quality. The proposed citizen science project builds on existing hydrology and water-quality expertise at the IIHR - Hydroscience & Engineering, University of Iowa.  IIHR - Hydroscience & Engineering also recently developed the Iowa Water Quality Information System, with which anyone with internet access can view real time water-quality information from sensors deployed across Iowa within its hydrologic context.  Immediate impacts of this project include the use of this tool to inform selection and placement of hundreds of conservation practices to reduce flooding and improve water quality in eight Iowa Watershed Approach project watersheds. The Iowa Department of Natural Resources may also adopt this new app for use by its volunteer water-quality monitoring program. The long-term implications for this project are the broader scientific community's potential adoption of a new water-quality measurement tool that allows anyone with a smartphone to take accurate measurements of water quality and share that data to a common online platform with very little effort or cost. The app will help researchers, state agencies, watershed managers, and the general public better monitor, understand, and characterize water-quality problems at the local watershed scale.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project are to 1) determine the feasibility of a smartphone-based application kit to accurately monitoring water quality; 2) assess user interest and engagement in using the kit; and 3) help stakeholders identify water quality ?hot spots? for potential implementation of projects to improve water quality. Below we summarize how the project goals were met.

Determining feasibility of smartphone-based application kit to accurately measure water quality. The data collected by volunteers showed that when looking at a large population of samples in aggregate, the smartphone tool measures NO3-N values similar to lab-generated results, with population data likely to vary by <10%. On an individual sample basis, the +30% error estimated by the company providing the app (Deltares, Inc.) seems to apply to our volunteer group. Since this error estimate was based on samplers from various backgrounds and experiences outside of Iowa, we believe the +30% connects to technological factors associated with the smartphone app. Deltares has indicated that the newly-developed colorimetric card is likely to improve accuracy and this will be a topic of future investigation for the research group. Overall, most of the volunteers found the tool to be easy to use and indications are that they were intrigued and enjoyed the immediate posting and access to the data. This is perhaps the best feature of the tool, i.e. the satisfaction the sampler gets by immediately seeing the result and how it compares with the larger population of samplers and samples. We will be working with Iowa Department of Natural Resources, to discuss using the recently defunded-IOWATER program resources in an effort to disseminate the tool to a larger population of volunteers.

Assessing User Interest and Engage in Using the Tool. This objective is quantified in more detail in the Center for Evaluation and Assessment section of the report (attached as a supplementary file). All indications are that the volunteers found the tool to be a vast improvement over the Hach test strips used without the smartphone camera/app. The app can be used by nearly anyone with a nominal time investment in training. However, measuring water quality in the field sometimes can be a challenge for even seasoned professionals with the best equipment. Many volunteers were frustrated at times while trying to obtain measurements with a high confidence level, and others had problems ?sending? the results to the website. Nonetheless, the volunteers did demonstrate that a large database of water quality data can be generated with a minimum investment of materials (strips, colorimetric cards) that do a reasonably good job of accurately characterizing water quality over large temporal and spatial scales. We also believe the project demonstrated that if data quality (accuracy and precision) is of high importance on a single sample at a single site, the app would not be a suitable replacement for lab analysis.

Helping stakeholders identify water quality ?hot spots? for potential implementation of projects to improve water quality. Nitrate levels in Iowa are elevated statewide and conservationists have an abundant supply of potential project areas. Many times, conservation choices are driven by pool of willing collaborators and not necessarily water quality data. This is true in both the Clear Creek and Cedar River watersheds. Nonetheless, the project volunteers in the Middle Cedar Watershed uncovered a tributary watershed (the headwater area of Otter Creek) that has not been expressly targeted for conservation or farmer engagement.  Much of the conservation work being done in the Middle Cedar Watershed has been done in Benton and Tama counties, i.e. sub-watersheds draining to the Cedar from the west. The Otter Creek watershed drains to the Cedar from the north and east, directly north of the city of Cedar Rapids. Many sites in this area near the town of Alice, Iowa, had nitrate levels of 10-20 mg/L (with one site >20 mg/L), providing the opportunity for future investigation of water quality and conservation opportunities in this area.

Deltares has developed a website to illustrate sample results generated by users of the app (https://publicwiki.deltares.nl/display/wqapp/Results). Users of the app are generally concentrated in the Netherlands and the Americas. As IIHR-UI has operated and maintained the Iowa Water Quality Information System (http://iwqis.iowawis.org/), an Iowa-centric water quality clearinghouse for real-time, continuous water quality data, it was our objective to integrate the smartphone app results into WQIS.

We developed a web interface to illustrate volunteer results generated by the smartphone app (https://iwqis.iowawis.org/volunteer/). The web site is publicly available and volunteer results were posted throughout the project, and continues to do so. In addition, the user can access the whole range of samples that have been measured at each site. A project web page was developed and posted to the PI?s website. This page is publicly available and all project volunteers continue to have access to the site (https://www.iihr.uiowa.edu/cjones/citizen-scientist-water-monitoring/).
